critique: This executive order amends a previous order (12353) regarding the Combined Federal Campaign, which allows voluntary health and welfare agencies to solicit contributions from federal employees. The amendment clarifies eligibility criteria for participating agencies, emphasizing direct health and welfare services to individuals or families and excluding agencies involved in political activity, advocacy, lobbying, or litigation. It also addresses international organizations and local agencies. The order aims to lessen the burdens of government and local communities in meeting health and welfare needs, while minimizing disruption of the federal workplace and avoiding the appearance of using federal resources for political purposes. It doesn't directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, or economic regulation in a significant way. The emphasis on charitable health and welfare agencies aligns with a moderate approach to social inclusion, favoring direct services over political advocacy.
